questions.question_text: A company wants to confirm sufficient executable space protection is in place for scenarios in which malware may be attempting buffer overflow attacks. Which of the following should the security engineer check?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. NX/XN
Key words "wants to confirm sufficient executable space protection."

Tough choice between NX/XN or ASLR. But there is no mention of the company using the special hardware required for NX/XN. Also, the question specifically states: "A company wants to confirm sufficient executable space protection." To me, that seems a bit more like ASLR.
I agree with A. ASLR randomizes the stack.

comments.content: Correct. ASLR is a technique involved in preventing exploitation of memory corruption vulnerabilities (such as a buffer overflow), by randomizing the stack. The company is specifically trying to prevent buffer overflow attacks. Again: there is no mention of the company using the special hardware required for NX/XN.

discussion.content:
B
NX bits mark certain pieces of memory as non-executable and require special hardware.
ASLR randomizes memory space to prevent buffer overruns and ensure there's always virtual memory available.

In computer security, executable-space protection marks memory regions as non-executable, such that an attempt to execute machine code in these regions will cause an exception. It makes use of hardware features such as the NX bit.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executable_space_protection
why is this not NX/XN?

questions.question_text:
Developers are working on a new feature to add to a social media platform. The new feature involves users uploading pictures of what they are currently doing.
The data privacy officer (DPO) is concerned about various types of abuse that might occur due to this new feature. The DPO states the new feature cannot be released without addressing the physical safety concerns of the platform's users.
Which of the following controls would BEST address the DPO's concerns?

discussion.content:
Question is how to protect physical safety.
We dont want attacker gain any info from the picture uploaded. Thus hiding the metadata would work in this case.

comments.content: The question says it's for a social media platform, not an application for work.

"Anybody, malicious or not, who is interested in what I am doing at work, almost certainly already knows the location of my workplace."

...dude, WHAT.

I am anybody, but I have no idea who you are or where you work. BUT if you uploaded an image of what you are currently doing at work (with the metadata) to a social media platform... I could potentially find out where you work.

"Hiding metadata would do nothing"
:S
given answer is correct

discussion.content: I don't think any of the solutions are adequate. Anybody, malicious or not, who is interested in what I am doing at work, almost certainly already knows the location of my workplace. Metadata is not relevant. Hiding metadata would do nothing.

choices.E: Forcing TLS for all connections on the platform
choices.C: Removing all metadata in the uploaded photo file
choices.D: Not displaying to the public who uploaded the photo
choices.B: Adding a one-hour delay of all uploaded photos
choices.A: Increasing blocking options available to the uploader

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A security consultant is considering authentication options for a financial institution. The following authentication options are available. Drag and drop the security mechanism to the appropriate use case. Options may be used once.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content: That makes indeed more sense, even if this question is weird in the first place!

discussion.content:
This is incorrect, the actual answers are.

Kerberos -1
SAML -2 
OTP-3
OAUTH-4

Kerberos- 3rd party network authentication tool
SAML- SSO between a Identity and Service provider
OTP- one time password
OAuth- for authorization not authentication

A project manager is working with a software development group to collect and evaluate user scenarios related to the organization’s internally designed data analytics tool. While reviewing stakeholder input, the project manager would like to formally document the needs of the various stakeholders and the associated organizational compliance objectives supported by the project.

Which of the following would be MOST appropriate to use?
Roles matrix
Peer review
BIA
SRTM

comments.content: SRTM is Security Requirements Traceability Matrix

discussion.content:
These should be the options to enable. 
Download programs from untrusted developers and manually install them - Side loading
Restrict apps from untrusted developers - Use Signed applications

Sandboxing or Containerisation is not an options that can be enabled in any modern MDM software. They are concepts.
Maybe D , because sandbonxing isolate fotware/apps. Agree with F.

comments.content: Answer E, because the keyword says: «...separate device profile»
I correct my self (sorry) Is Containerization , because sandoboxing (main use) is for testing.

discussion.content: The answer is EF

comments.content:
Agree the answer is side loading and signed applications.
The problem is: the entire organization is allowed to install unauthorized apps. This means that apps do not have to be signed, and side loading apps is allowed. Those practices must be stopped, for all but the development team.

discussion.content: I disagree with the idea that it could be containerization. The definition of containerization in mobile devices is “ isolating corporate data into a protected and encrypted container stored on the mobile device”. What you all are referring to is assigning configuration profiles to separate dev team from others. With that said, I believe the answer is side loading and signed applications. It doesn’t say they would be toggled at the same time. So you would toggle the ability to side load unsigned apps for the dev team and secure for everyone else.
the answer is EF

I agree that one of the answers has to be containerization. So that means sandbox cant be the other answer. 

I'm more inclined to pick signed applications
The separate device would suggest a sandbox

E. Containerization - To ensure the dev team still has access to secured company data.
F. Signed applications - To ensure everyone else is compliant

questions.question_text: A security analyst is reviewing the corporate MDM settings and notices some disabled settings, which consequently permit users to download programs from untrusted developers and manually install them. After some conversations, it is confirmed that these settings were disabled to support the internal development of mobile applications. The security analyst is now recommending that developers and testers have a separate device profile allowing this, and that the rest of the organization's users do not have the ability to manually download and install untrusted applications. Which of the following settings should be toggled to achieve the goal? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. VoIP (maybe not email?)
Nobody here has addressed video conferencing, although it is specifically addressed in the question. Everybody thinks email needs to be configured, although that is not addressed in the question.
Why VoIP? Consider:
"Group video calls enable your team to collaborate over your existing VoIP solution."
"Video conferencing benefits . . . HD quality. Provide the best experience for attendees by using a proven VoIP platform."
"Built on the same technology as VoIP phones, team video calls are easy and fast to set up."
https://www.nextiva.com/features/voip/video-conferencing.html

comments.content:
Agree with approach to the answer. Feel like this question is either dated and badly worded on purpose. There was an MCSE cert for messaging specialty. But its focus was mainly on Exchange server. There were some elements of yammer and Lync as well. In that context i'd pick D. the term presence is mainly used in VoIP application where a soft phone can show presence. Essentially, skype, lynch or teams these days will show online, available, offline, busy.etc...thats presence. For that reason E makes sense. 
The video conferencing is where it gets confusing. I feel thats a detractor to a degree. Lync, skype and teams today can provide video conferencing. So IM has to be the only other answer that fits.

"the term presence is mainly used in VoIP"
I think VoIP may also need to be configured for video conferencing. Maybe email and VoIP?

discussion.content:
✑ Secure messaging between internal users using digital signatures
"Messaging" wold seem to imply instant messaging. But it could mean email. Usually digital signatures do not apply to instant messaging. Therefore: Email
✑ Secure sites for video-conferencing sessions
Where is this addressed by any of the options? Certainly this is not addressed by email, or instant messaging, although everybody seems to think those are the answers. Maybe this is just not something that the company can configure? 
✑ Presence information for all office employees
What do they mean by "presence information?" Just to know the employee is there? Or do they want to know where the employee is located? IM will tell you if an employee is logged on to the IM. But what is there to configure? 
✑ Restriction of certain types of messages to be allowed into the network.
What kind of message? Email? IM? Both? I suppose an argument could be made for email, and IM.

comments.content: I hate these kinds of posts. Baseless assertions are completely meaningless. Please post your reasoning, or don't bother posting.

discussion.content: D&E are correct
The would seem to include email. But the requirements do not.
Although the question mentions RDP, the requirements do not. D and E

questions.question_text:
Within the past six months, a company has experienced a series of attacks directed at various collaboration tools. Additionally, sensitive information was compromised during a recent security breach of a remote access session from an unsecure site. As a result, the company is requiring all collaboration tools to comply with the following:
✑ Secure messaging between internal users using digital signatures
✑ Secure sites for video-conferencing sessions
✑ Presence information for all office employees
✑ Restriction of certain types of messages to be allowed into the network.
Which of the following applications must be configured to meet the new requirements? (Choose two.)
